metadata.title: Screening of additives for droplet qRT-PCR thermocycling enables single influenza A virus 1 genome quantification 2 3

body_text.text: The miniaturization of real time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) using 19 drop-based microfluidics, or droplet qPCR, allows for quantification of single nucleic acids. The 20 nucleic acids are compartmentalized into aqueous microdroplets, picoliters in volume, separated 21 by an immiscible oil, and stabilized by a surfactant. In droplet qPCR, accurate data can only be 22 obtained if the drops remain stable to coalescence upon thermocycling and drop contents do not 23 diffuse to neighboring drops. In this work, we present a droplet qRT-PCR assay for quantifying 24 influenza A virus (IAV) following systematic testing of different PCR additives, resulting in the 25 optimal combination of Tween-20 / BSA / betaine to maintain drop stability and limit dye 26 diffusion. We use a standard qPCR machine to generate real time amplification curves of 27 hundreds of thousands of drops and correlate this data with constructed amplification curves 28 obtained from hundreds of drops sampled at various cycle numbers and imaged using 29 epifluorescence microscopy. To demonstrate the utility of our method, we tested a range of in 30 vitro transcribed M gene and IAV viral supernatant from infected cells. We directly amplified 31 IAV genomes from infected supernatant without an RNA extraction step. Our droplet qPCR 32 assay enables detection of IAV down to 0.274 cpd, or a single viral genome per drop, 33 establishing the high sensitivity and precision of our method. 34 35 36 37 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 /2020 quantification of genomic content in drops. 19 To maintain drop stability and dye retention, 69 droplet PCR assays stabilized with PEG-PFPE2 use high surfactant concentrations (2-5 wt %) 8, 15, 70 20 , small drop sizes (<40 µm diameter), and/or incorporated additives. The most common 71 additives used for droplet PCR assays are polyethylene glycol (PEG), Tween-20, bovine serum 72 albumin (BSA), and betaine; yet systematic testing of the effect of these additives is critically 73 lacking and, to our knowledge, has not been previously reported. Systematic testing would 74 provide an optimized set of additives for droplet qPCR by improving drop stability during 75 thermocycling and limiting transport of small molecules between drops. 76

Here, we investigate a range of additives for optimizing droplet quantitative reverse 77 transcriptase PCR (qRT-PCR) and enabling quantification of influenza A virus (IAV) in 100 µm 78 diameter drops. Additive combinations of PEG, Tween-20, BSA, and betaine were screened for 79 their ability to stabilize drops from coalescence and limit diffusion between neighboring drops. 80

Together with 3 wt% (w/w) of PEG-PFPE2 surfactant 13 in the oil phase, an additive combination 81 of 1% w/v Tween-20, 0.8 µg/µl BSA, and 1 M betaine in a standard qRT-PCR mixture was 82 found to be optimal for stabilizing drops and limiting dye diffusion under qPCR thermocycling 83 between 60 °C and 95 °C. Using Tween-20 / BSA / betaine as additives, five orders of 84 magnitude of in vitro transcribed viral RNA was resolved between drops ranging from 10 -1 to 85 10 4 copies per drop (cpd). Drops containing low (10 1 cpd) and high (10 4 cpd) viral RNA 86 concentrations were thermocycled using a standard qPCR machine and the qRT-PCR 87 amplification curves were comparable to constructed curves obtained from drops sampled at 88 various cycles using epifluorescence microscopy. The optimized droplet qRT-PCR assay was 89 used to quantify the number of A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) IAV genomes present in the 90 supernatant from infected A549 cells. At 24 hours post infection (hpi), we prepared six dilutions 91 of supernatant from infected cells to determine our detection limit for live virus. Using ddPCR 92 analysis, we were able to quantify IAV RNA directly from infected cells across four orders of 93 magnitude. We find that our limit of detection is at a dilution that corresponds to 0.274 cpd, 94 demonstrating that we are able to detect down to a single viral genome in a drop. In addition, we 95 amplified viral RNA from supernatant collected directed from infected cells without an RNA 96 extraction step. This direct PCR method will have impact in reducing the number of steps for 97 future work performing droplet qPCR of viruses. 98 99 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. Tween-20/BSA, Tween-20/PEG-6K and Tween20/BSA/betaine with concentrations as 154 previously described). The continuous phase consisted of a 3 wt% (w/w) solution of PEG-155 PFPE2-based surfactant (RAN Biotechnologies, 008-FluoroSurfactant) in fluorinated HFE7500 156 oil (3 M). The dispersed and continuous phases were loaded in 1-mL syringes and injected into 157 the drop making microfluidic devices at a flow rate of 800 µL/h and 1600 μL/h, respectively, 158 using syringe pumps (New Era NE-1000) controlled by a custom LabVIEW (2015) program to 159 generate drops. A total volume of 60 µL composed of approximately 20 µL of drops and 40 µL 160 of oil were collected in 100 µL PCR tubes (Applied Biosystems). Drops were imaged using 195 epifluorescence microscopy to quantify fluorescence from the FAM (6-carboxyfluorescein) dye-196 labeled TaqMan probe and ROX (6-carboxy-X-rhodamine) reference dye. body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.065342 doi: bioRxiv preprint
body_text.section: Brightfield and fluorescence imaging of drops during thermocycling 193

body_text.text: Screening of qRT-PCR additives to stabilize drops and reduce dye diffusion during 230 thermocycling 231

To probe how different PCR additives impact drop stability and dye diffusion during 232 thermocycling, we measured the effect of Tween-20, BSA, PEG-6K, and betaine individually 233 and in different combinations in a droplet qRT-PCR assay with 3 wt% (w/w) of PEG-PFPE2 234 surfactant. To analyze drop stability, drop diameters D were measured post thermocycling from 235 epifluorescence images. To quantify dye diffusion, fluorescence intensities of a thermally stable 236 reference dye (ROX) that is present in all droplet qPCR assays was measured post thermocycling 237 from epifluorescence images. All of the droplet qRT-PCR assays were optimized for TaqMan-238 based chemistry to detect and quantify in vitro transcribed M gene RNA from IAV. The M gene 239 is a standard target for IAV detection due to its conserved nature across different IAV species. 21, 240 28 Drops were produced from a solution of qRT-PCR reaction master mix, probe and primers, 241 enzymes and 10 7 copies/µL (~170 cpd) of M gene template. This represents the qRT-PCR 242 reaction mixture with no additives. To test different PCR additives, the qRT-PCR reaction 243 mixture was supplemented with each of the following: BSA, PEG-6K, betaine, Tween-20, 244

Tween-20 / PEG-6K, Tween-20 / BSA, or Tween-20 / BSA / betaine. PEG enhances PCR 245 reactions due to its ability to act as a macromolecular crowding agent, thereby increasing DNA 246 polymerase activity. 29 In drops, PEG has been shown to improve the stability of drops containing 247 high salt content which can occur in standard PCR reaction mix. 30-32 BSA is a common PCR 248 additive and has been shown previously to limit dye diffusion between drops. 33, 34 Tween-20 has 249 been utilized as an additional surfactant 8, 35, 36 and acts to reduce surface tension in drops while 250 betaine improves PCR amplification of GC rich regions by reducing the formation of nucleic 251 acid secondary structure. 37-39 252

The drops containing 10 7 copies/µL of M gene template were thermocycled on a standard 253 qPCR machine with a 30-minute reverse transcriptase step followed by 40 cycles of PCR. Drops 254 were imaged on an epifluorescence microscope following thermocycling in order to assess drop 255 stability from coalescence and retention of the ROX dye. The images of drops that contained no 256 additives, BSA alone, PEG-6K alone, or betaine alone show extensive coalescence with multiple 257 different drop sizes in each image (Fig. 1A) . Diameters D were compared to the initial drop 258 diameter D0 before thermocycling of drops with no PCR additives. Normalized diameters (D-259 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. were the most stable following thermocycling (Fig. 1B, orange box) . 278

In addition to drop stability, we also investigated the retention of ROX reference dye 279 within drops after thermocycling. The fluorescence intensity I of ROX in each of the 280 epifluorescence images was normalized by subtracting the background signal IB. The normalized 281 ROX fluorescence intensity of each drop, I-IB, was measured to quantify diffusion of the dye 282 from the drops (Fig. 1C) . A lower value of I-IB indicates that the ROX dye diffused out of the 283 drops and not between neighboring drops. To verify this, we measured the background 284 fluorescence of the oil surrounding the drops and found that the background fluorescence 285 intensity was highest for the no additive condition (Fig. S2) , indicating that the additives tested 286
here had a positive effect on ROX dye retention in drops during thermocycling. 287

A narrow ROX I-IB within drops (smaller CV) is ideal for normalizing the TaqMan probe 288 signal that is produced during thermocycling. In addition, a high I-IB indicates that the dye is not 289 diffusing out of the drops. Thus, we tested drop additives to look for a narrow distribution CV 290 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.065342 doi: bioRxiv preprint and overall high ROX fluorescence intensity (Fig. 1C) . With no additives, I-IB of the ROX dye 291 was 33.6 a.u., the lowest of all eight conditions tested, and indicates a loss of ROX dye from the 292 drops during thermocycling. Based on our data, Tween-20 and the Tween-20 / BSA / betaine 293 combination maintained the best drop stability post thermocycling. In terms of ROX dye 294 retention, Tween-20 had the highest I-IB of 99.6 a.u. (Fig. 1C, red box) compared to Tween-20 / 295 BSA / betaine with a I-IB of 89.7 a.u. (Fig. 1C, orange box) . However, the Tween-20 / BSA / 296 betaine condition resulted in a smaller CV (15.9%) of I-IB than the Tween-20 condition (18.5%). 297

Based on our results, droplet qRT-PCR reactions that contain an additive combination of Tween-298 20 / BSA / betaine have the lowest change in drop diameters following thermocycling with 299 relatively high overall ROX fluorescence intensity and the lowest CV of the fluorescence 300 intensity. Numbers of drops measured and statistical information from Fig. 1B -C can be found in 301 Table S1 . 302 303 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. To evaluate the reaction efficiency of our droplet qRT-PCR reaction with the optimized 319 additives Tween-20 / BSA / betaine, we performed a dilution series of RNA in drops and as bulk 320
body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: reactions. PCR is based on the principle that amplification begins in an exponential growth phase 321 at early thermocycles before the reaction products become exhausted. This exponential phase 322 corresponds to a reaction efficiency of 100%, where all DNA is multiplied by a factor of two at 323 the completion of every cycle. Desired amplification efficiencies should fall between 90-324 110%. 42, 43 PCR efficiencies that fall outside of this range will limit dynamic range and 325 sensitivity. A dilution series of a known quantity of target RNA or DNA is required to create a 326 standard curve to relate cycle threshold (Ct) values to the common logarithm (log10) of the RNA 327 or DNA concentration. When a standard curve has a slope of -3.33, it indicates that the PCR 328 reaction efficiency is 100%. To perform a standard curve in drops, in vitro transcribed IAV M 329 gene RNA was added as template to the optimized qRT-PCR reaction mix with additives Tween-330 20 / BSA / betaine. Serial RNA dilutions of a range of 10 4 to 10 9 copies/µL in bulk were 331 generated, corresponding to a range of 10 -1 to 10 4 cpd. The amplification curves obtained using 332 qPCR in bulk (Fig. S3) follow the same trend as in drops (Fig. 2A) . The Ct values for the 333 dilution series in drops and in bulk were plotted to generate standard curves for both reactions 334 (Fig. 2B) . The slopes of the curves yield a droplet reaction efficiency of 90.3% compared to a 335 bulk reaction efficiency of 98.9%, with both falling within the desired 90-110% range (Fig. 2B) . 336
body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: We hypothesize that the lower efficiency in the droplet reactions compared to bulk is due to 337 sequestration of reagents within the drops, resulting in a slightly reduced ability to fully amplify 338 the DNA over 40 cycles before exhaustion of required reaction reagents. 339
body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: An end-point measurement of the drop fluorescence can be performed either with 340 epifluorescence microscopy or custom flow-based detection methods. 1, 2, 24 Here, we used 341 epifluorescence microscopy. Drops from the dilution series in Fig 2A were imaged on an 342 epifluorescence microscope after 40 PCR cycles. Representative images of FAM and ROX 343 signals in drops containing 10 4 (Fig. 2C) and 10 -1 (Fig. 2D ) RNA cpd are shown. As expected, 344 the 10 4 cpd case resulted in all bright drops due to the high concentration of RNA amplified in 345 each drop, while the 10 -1 cpd case resulted in a combination of bright and dark drops due to the 346 limiting dilution of RNA. We performed ddPCR analysis by counting the number of bright 347 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.065342 doi: bioRxiv preprint versus dark drops from the endpoint reactions of the dilution series. Poisson statistics was used to 348 fit the fraction of positive drops from the dilution series images, following Eq. 1: 349
body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: where λ is the average copy numbers of target RNA and p is the fraction of positive drops. 1 The 351 percentage of amplified drops demonstrated good agreement with Poisson statistics (Fig. 2E , 352 Table S2 ). At 10 -1 cpd and 10 0 cpd, there were 14.2% and 38.1% amplified drops, respectively, 353 while at higher concentrations (10 1 through 10 4 cpd) the number of amplified drops reached 354 100%, following the Poisson estimate for calculating RNA concentration through ddPCR. Our 355 results demonstrate that our optimized qRT-PCR reaction mix maintained drop stability and 356 prevented dye transport between drops, allowing us to normalize the fluorescent signal from the 357 TaqMan FAM probe in amplified drops. In addition, our droplet qRT-PCR exhibited a high PCR 358 reaction efficiency of 90.3%, which was within the desired range of 90-110% for qPCR 359 reactions. 360 361 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. body_text.section: Dilution series demonstrates high efficiency for droplet qRT-PCR 318

body_text.text: Concentration of nucleic acid present within a sample can be determined using qRT-376 PCR. In the prior section, we introduced a novel method for testing qRT-PCR additives to obtain 377 amplification curves across five orders of magnitude of M gene RNA in drops. Here, we 378 performed a high-resolution investigation of two concentrations of M gene in drops undergoing 379 real-time PCR amplification. We studied drops containing low (10 1 cpd) and high (10 4 cpd) viral 380 RNA by sampling drops at various cycle numbers on the qRT-PCR machine and imaging under 381 epifluorescence microscopy. We obtained real-time PCR amplification curves from the 382 thermocycled drops in the qPCR machine and compared these curves to constructed 383 amplification curves arising from hundreds of individual drops imaged using epifluorescence 384 microcopy. 385
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: Amplifying RNA within drops on a standard qPCR machine generated amplification 386 curves of all the drops contained within the sample tube, approximately 300,000 drops. The 387 qPCR machine tracks fluorescence amplification of all drops in the tube at each cycle number 388 between 0 to 40, which we call continuous data. We sampled hundreds of randomly sampled 389 drops imaged on an epifluorescence microscope over multiple thermocycles, which we call 390 discontinuous data. This allowed us to construct amplification curves using microscopy that 391 resembled the real-time continuous measurements performed on the standard qPCR machine. 392
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: Thermocycling drops within the qPCR machine without interruption generated a continuous 393 amplification curve (Fig. 3A, green solid line) and is representative of a bulk sample (Fig. S3) . 394
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: By contrast, a discontinuous amplification curve was produced by imaging drops from individual 395 tubes at specific cycles on an epifluorescence microscope (Fig. 3A, blue dashed line) . Drops 396 from the low RNA loading condition were analyzed across eight cycles (cycle 1, 20, 22, 24, 26, 397 28, 30, and 40) (Fig. 3A) . Cycle 1 provides a baseline fluorescence measurement. At cycle 20, 398 the amplification curve begins to increase exponentially. Drops are then imaged after every two 399 cycles from cycle 20 to 30 to capture the exponential region of the amplification curve. A final 400 endpoint measurement is taken at cycle 40. The normalized fluorescence data from the 401 epifluorescence images (Fig. 3A, blue dashed line) are plotted for each cycle measured and 402 produce a curve similar to that of the qPCR machine (Fig. 3A, green solid line) , validating that 403 an amplification curve can be constructed from the discontinuous epifluorescence data. The 404 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.065342 doi: bioRxiv preprint distributions of drop fluorescence from epifluorescence images at cycles 1, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30, 405 and 40 for the low RNA loading condition are presented in Fig. 3B . As amplification starts to 406 increase at cycle 20, the distribution of drops shifts to the right as the fluorescence increases. 407
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: From cycle 20 to 30, we observed that a majority of the drops began to amplify while a small 408 population did not (Fig. 3B, arrow, cycle 40) , forming a bimodal distribution. We hypothesize 409 that this small population of non-amplifying drops did not contain template RNA. This would 410 indicate that the 1.7 x 10 1 cpd loading was an overestimate as empty drops are not expected at 411 this concentration. In comparison, the high RNA loading condition (1.7 x 10 4 cpd) should result 412 in every drop containing RNA, with all drops amplifying in unison, and should not result in a 413 bimodal distribution as observed with the low RNA loading condition. To test this, drops 414 containing 1.7 x 10 4 RNA cpd were imaged at 0, 10, 15 and 40 cycles (Fig. 3C) . As with the low 415 RNA loading condition, the normalized fluorescence data from the high RNA loading condition 416 epifluorescence images produced a curve (Fig. 3C , red dashed line) similar to that of the qPCR 417 machine (Fig. 3C, orange line) . The distributions of drop fluorescence at each cycle for the high 418 RNA loading condition are presented in Fig 3D. 419
body_text.section: Generation of droplet PCR amplification curves from direct qRT-PCR thermocycling 374 compared to epifluorescence microscopy 375

body_text.text: As discrete particles such as RNA are encapsulated into drops following a Poisson 420 distribution, 24 we predicted the high RNA loading condition (1.7 x 10 4 cpd) would create a tight 421 distribution (CV = 0.77%) while the low RNA loading condition (1.7 x 10 1 cpd) would create a 422 wide distribution (CV = 24.3%) of RNA between drops, respectively. The CV is calculated as 423 4 " # , as defined by the Poisson distribution, where λ is the RNA loading in cpd. The high RNA 424 loading condition resulted in all drops amplifying as predicted. In addition, the fluorescence 425 intensities of the high loading RNA condition showed tighter distributions at all cycles compared 426 to the amplified drops in the low RNA loading conditions. Representative images of drops for 427 both 1.7 x 10 1 and 1.7 x 10 4 cpd at early and late cycles provide a visual reference for the 428 distributions in the histograms (Fig. 3E) . The similar trend of drop measurements between the 429 qPCR machine and the epifluorescence images demonstrates that RNA concentrations in 430 individual drops can be extrapolated from real-time PCR amplification curves produced by either 431 standard qPCR thermocycling or epifluorescence microscopy. These methods can therefore be 432 utilized to determine nucleic acid concentrations from a large population of drops without the 433 need for custom flow-based methods. 1, 2, 24 434 435 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. body_text.text: Following successful amplification of in vitro transcribed RNA, we applied our 461 optimized droplet qRT-PCR assay to quantify the number of IAV genomes present in the 462 supernatant from infected cells using ddPCR analysis. We infected A549 supernatant results in every drop amplifying after 40 cycles (Fig. 4B) . In comparison, a 10 -2 484 dilution of supernatant, which we estimated to contain 1.75 cpd, results in a majority of drops 485 amplifying (77%) with a few that remain dark (Fig. 4C) . The lowest 10 -5 dilution of supernatant 486 from infected cells is similar to supernatant from mock infected cells and is therefore 487 representative of background amplification (Fig. 4D and E) . Our limit of detection was reached 488 at a 10 -3 dilution level, in which N+/Ntotal was measured to be 0.274 cpd. This demonstrates the 489 ability of our droplet qPCR assay to detect viral RNA down to a single cpd. Thus, we 490 was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder. All rights reserved. body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint (which this version posted April 28, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.28.065342 doi: bioRxiv preprint
body_text.section: qRT-PCR amplification and quantification of live influenza A virus 460

body_text.text: In this work, we present a droplet qRT-PCR assay for quantifying IAV following 508 systematic testing of different PCR additives, resulting in the optimal combination of Tween-20 / 509 BSA / betaine to maintain drop stability and limit dye diffusion. We demonstrate, for the first 510 time, the ability to use a standard qPCR machine to generate real time amplification curves of 511 hundreds of thousands of drops. We correlate this data with hundreds of drops sampled using 512 epifluorescence microscopy. Measurements of real-time PCR amplification in drops using a 513 standard qPCR machine or epifluorescence microscope can eliminate the need for complicated 514 custom microfluidic thermocycling devices 3-5 . As qPCR machines and epifluorescence 515 microscopes are common instruments in many laboratories, this method can be used to 516 systematically test droplet qPCR additives for quantifying genomes within a large population of 517 drops. 518

We tested a wide concentration range of both in vitro transcribed viral RNA and viral 519 supernatant from infected cells in drops. Our optimized droplet qPCR assay enabled 520 quantification of 10 -1 to 10 4 cpd of in vitro transcribed IAV M gene. To further demonstrate the 521 utility of our method, we quantified viral IAV genomes from infected cells. Using ddPCR, we 522 measured IAV RNA over four orders of magnitude down to 0.274 cpd, or a single viral genome 523 per drop. This demonstrates the high sensitivity and precision of our droplet qPCR assay. 524 Importantly, our work establishes the ability to directly amplify viral RNA without the need for 525 RNA extraction and with very little reagent, which is advantageous in challenging resource-526 limited situations such as the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe our findings will have great 527 impact in future studies for accurately quantifying viral genomes using droplet qPCR. 528 529 530 531 532 533 534 535

FIGREF0.text: 163 Endpoint brightfield and fluorescence imaging of drops containing PCR additives 164 combinations 165 Thermocycled drops were imaged by injecting 20 µL of drops into a microfluidic device with a 166 wide inlet channel large enough to capture a full field of view (FOV) of drops with a 10x 167 objective. The channel height of the device was 50 μm. Brightfield and fluorescence images 168 (Texas RED (TXRED, ex. 540-580 nm, em. 592-669 nm)) of the drops were captured on an 169 inverted epifluorescence microscope (Leica DMi8) with a 10x objective (Leica, NA 0.32). The 170 Leica Application Suite X was used for image acquisition. For each of the eight additive 171 conditions, drops were imaged from three PCR tubes and three FOV per tube (>100 drops per 172 FOV) were captured. 173 Analysis of endpoint brightfield and fluorescence imaging of drops containing 174 combinations of PCR additives 175 Drops imaged on the epifluorescence microscope were processed with a custom MATLAB 176 (R2019a) script to measure drop diameter and ROX fluorescence intensity. Measurements of 177 drop diameters D from at least 270 drops per condition were made following thermocycling. All 178 drop measurements were made on the TXRED channel of the acquired images. ROX 179 fluorescence intensities I were normalized by subtracting the background fluorescence IB. 180 Background fluorescence was set as the average pixel value measured from a small (100 px 2 ) 181 background region in the middle of the image using FIJI. 26 The device used for imaging had a 182 channel height of 50 µm, thereby compressing drops larger than 50 μm in diameter and skewing 183 larger drop diameter measurements. Thus, drop diameters greater than this height were adjusted 184 by estimating the compressed drops as oblate spheroids and then using the oblate spheroid 185 volume to calculate the equivalent sphere diameter using the equation ! = # " # ℎ ! where DS is 186 the diameter of the equivalent sphere, DE is the measured diameter of a compressed drop, and h 187 is the channel height of 50 μm. Normalization of measured D from an initial drop diameter D0 188 was determined with the equation ( − $ )/ $ . The initial D0 is the average drop diameter 189 measured from drops without PCR additives upon exit from a drop making device as shown in 190 Fig. S1. D0 was used to normalize the diameter of drops that contained different additives 191 following thermocycling.

FIGREF2.text: drops from each tube at each cycle on the epifluorescence microscope for an average 198 of 650 drops after pooling from all FOV (≈0.02% of the drops contained in the PCR tube). The 199 fluorescence intensities of individual drops were measured using a custom MATLAB script 200 (R2019a). 201 Analysis of brightfield and fluorescence imaging of drops during thermocycling 202 Drops imaged on the epifluorescence microscope were processed with a custom MATLAB 203 (R2019a) script to measure FAM fluorescence intensity. The FAM fluorescence intensities 204 measured during qRT-PCR were normalized as ∆ % / %,$ , where the qPCR normalized reporter 205 value RN is defined as % = '() / *+, , ∆ % = % − %,-./01230 , IFAM is the FAM intensity at 206 each cycle, IROX is the ROX intensity at each cycle, RN,baseline is the average RN value of the first 207 three cycles, and RN,0 is the initial RN value. 208 Virus strains and cell lines 209 The IAV virus strain used in the present study was A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) (kindly 210 provided by Dr. Christopher Brooke). Viral A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) stocks were 211 propagated and titered on Madin-Darby Canine Kidney (MDCK) cells (kindly provided by Dr. 212 Agnieszka Rynda-Apple). MDCK cells were propagated in DMEM (Corning) media 213 supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (HyClone) and 1x Penicillin/Streptomycin (Fisher 214 Scientific). All experimental infections were performed on human alveolar epithelial A549 cells 215 (kindly provided by Dr. Christopher Brooke). A549 cells were propagated in Hams F-12 media 216 (Corning) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 1x Penicillin/Streptomycin. 217 Virus infections 218 A549 cells were seeded into 6-well plates with 1 x 10 6 cells per well. The cells were infected 219 with the H1N1 virus at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.1 in infection media consisting of 220 Hams F-12 supplemented with 1-mM HEPES (HyClone), 1x Penicillin/Streptomycin (Fisher 221 Scientific) and 0.1% BSA (MP Biomedical). Infection with the H1N1 virus was performed in the 222

FIGREF3.text: /D0 closer to zero indicate less change in drop diameter after thermocycling. The (D-D0)/D0 260 of the various additive combinations in Fig. 1B demonstrate that drops containing no additives, 261 or only a single additive of BSA, PEG-6K, or betaine, had high deviation from zero, a wide 262 distribution of diameters, and a large number of outliers as represented by individual dots. The 263 addition of Tween-20 alone to the PCR reaction mix resulted in a tight distribution of drop 264diameters. However, (D-D0)/D0 was below zero with a value of -0.12, indicating that the Tween-265 20 drops decreased in size from their initial diameters(Fig. 1B, red box). As the addition of 266Tween-20 decreased drop coalescence upon thermocycling, we proceeded to test different 267 combinations of the additives with Tween-20. Tween-20 was combined with PEG-6K, BSA and 268 BSA / betaine. The individual additives PEG-6K, BSA, and betaine were chosen as they were 269 utilized in prior droplet PCR assays.20, 35, 40, 41  By adding Tween-20 to each of these additives, 270 (D-D0)/D0 decreased below zero and were found to have lower coefficients of variation (CV) 271 than with no additives and with each of the additives alone without Tween-20(Fig. 1B). The 272 measured diameters indicate that the addition of Tween-20 greatly decreased both drop 273 coalescence and CV, although epifluorescence images show that Tween-20 / PEG-6K and 274 Tween-20 / BSA combinations still contained a number of large drops, indicating that the 275 problem of coalescence was not fully resolved. The combination of Tween-20 / BSA / betaine 276 drops resulted in (D-D0)/D0 closest to zero at -0.04 with very few outliers, indicating these drops 277

FIGREF5.text: qRT-PCR dilution series of in vitro transcribed IAV M gene in drops 363 (A) Amplification curves of six 10-fold dilutions of M gene RNA amplified in drops ranging 364 from 10 -1 to 10 4 copies of RNA per drop (cpd). (B) Ct standard curves for the bulk and drop 365 amplification curves. The calculated qRT-PCR reaction efficiency was 90.3% for the drop 366 dilution series and 98.9% for the bulk dilutions series, which falls within the desired range (90% 367 to 110%). Representative epifluorescence images of the FAM and corresponding ROX channels 368 of drops containing (C) 10 4 cpd and (D) 10 -1 cpd after 40 thermocycles. (E) Droplet digital PCR 369

FIGREF6.text: Comparison of droplet qRT-PCR amplification curves generated using a 437 standard qPCR machine and epifluorescence imaging 438 Drops containing (A) 10 1 M gene RNA cpd were thermocycled using qPCR. The solid green line 439 represents real-time continuous fluorescence measurements of drops at each cycle as determined 440 by qPCR, whereas the blue dashed line represents fluorescence measurements of sampled 441 individual drops at cycle numbers 1, 20, 22, 24, 26, 28, 30, and 40 as determined by 442 epifluorescence microscopy. Shaded error bars represent one standard deviation. (B) Histograms 443 of individual drop fluorescence values from the epifluorescence images for 10 1 M gene RNA cpd 444 show an increase in the fluorescence intensity from cycle 20 to 30. Cycle 1 and 40 represent pre-445 and post-thermocycling. N represents the number of drops analyzed from multiple 446 epifluorescence images for each cycle. The arrow in cycle 40 represents unamplified drops 447 present in our low RNA loading condition. (C) 10 4 M gene RNA cpd were thermocycled using 448 Shaded error bars represent one standard deviation. (D) Histograms of individual 452 drop fluorescence values from the epifluorescence images for 10 4 M gene RNA cpd show an 453 increase in the fluorescence intensity from cycle 15 to 40. Cycle 1 and 40 represent pre-and 454 post-thermocycling. N represents the number of drops analyzed from multiple epifluorescence 455 images for each cycle. (E) Changes in fluorescence as cycle numbers increase are observed from 456 representative epifluorescence images of 10 1 or 10 4 M gene RNA cpd at cycles 22 and

FIGREF7.text: cells, a human alveolar 463 epithelial cell line, with the A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) IAV at a low MOI of 0.1. At 24 h post 464infection, we prepared six dilutions of supernatant from infected cells starting with undiluted, or 465 10 0 dilution, down to a 10 -5 dilution. Supernatant from mock infected cells was included as a 466 control to determine the level of background amplification and the detection limit for live virus. 467Infected supernatant dilutions and undiluted supernatant from mock infected cells were added to 468 the optimized qRT-PCR master mix and drops were produced, thermocycled, and analyzed on 469 the epifluorescence microscope. In this case, the virus was heat lysed during the reverse 470 transcription step at 60 °C for 30 min and then amplified without an RNA extraction step. This 471 direct PCR method allowed us to perform ddPCR directly from the supernatant of infected cells 472to quantify the amount of RNA present. We measured the fraction of positive drops to total drops 473 (N+/Ntotal), also defined as p in Eq. 1 and plotted this as a function of dilution factor(Fig. 4A, 474blue solid line). A Poisson fit with an R 2 value of 0.987 was used to estimate the average number 475 of IAV genomes per drop at each dilution(Fig. 4A, green dashed line, Table S2). The undiluted 476 supernatant was estimated to contain 175 cpd, corresponding to 3.34 x 10 6 copies/µL. We477 compared this value to the measured concentration of the undiluted supernatant obtained using 478 qRT-PCR. The Ct value of the undiluted supernatant resulted in a concentration of 1.96 x 10 6 479 copies/µL, based upon the standard curve from Fig. 2A, in agreement with our Poisson estimate. 480 The supernatant dilutions (Fig. 4A, solid blue line) followed the Poisson fit down to the 10 -3 481 dilution (0.175 cpd). The background amplification level of mock infected cells was 0.082 cpd 482 (Fig. 4A, red dashed line). Representative images are shown and demonstrate that undiluted 483

The dashed line is used to show that the Tween-20 and Tween-20 / BSA / betaine 559 additive conditions had the lowest normalized background, indicating the best retention of ROX 560 dye in the drops during thermocycling. TABREF0.text: ammonium acetate/ethanol according to the manufacturer's instructions. RNA concentration was 131 quantified using a NanoDrop spectrophotometer and used to determine the copy number per µL. 132Microfluidic device fabrication 133Microfluidic devices for making 50 μm and 100 μm diameter drops were fabricated by 134patterning SU-8 photoresist (Microchem SU-8 3050) on silicon wafers (University Wafer, ID# 135 447, test grade) using standard photolithography techniques. 24 Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) 136 (Sylgard 184) at 10:1 mass ratio of polymer to cross-linking agent is poured onto the patterned 137 device master molds. Air was purged from the uncured PDMS by placing the filled mold in a 138 vacuum chamber for at least 1 h. The PDMS was cured in an oven at 55 °C for 24 h and then 139 removed from the mold with a scalpel. Ports were punched into the PDMS slab with a 0.75 mm 140 diameter biopsy punch (EMS Rapid-Core, Electron Microscopy Sciences). The PDMS slab was 141 bonded to a 2-in by 3-in glass slide (VWR micro slides, cat. #48382-179) after plasma treatment 142 (Harrick Plasma PDC-001) for 60 s at high power (30 W) and 700 mTorr oxygen pressure. The 143 drop making devices were made hydrophobic by flowing Aquapel (Pittsburgh Glass Works) 144 through the channels, followed by blowing the channels with air filtered through a GVS 145 ABLUO™ 25 mm 0.2-μm filter (Fisher Scientific) before baking the devices in an oven at 55 °C 146 for 1 h. 147 Flow-focusing drop making devices were used to make 50 µm diameter drops for the drop 149 stability and PCR dilution experiments and 100 µm diameter drops for infected supernatant 150 experiments. 25 The dispersed phase consisted of qRT-PCR mix containing a range of 151 concentrations (10 3 to 10 8 copies/µL) of in vitro transcribed M gene RNA and different 152 combinations of additives (no additives, Tween-20 only, BSA only, PEG-6K only, betaine only, 153
